sentence: The benchmark averages were mixed at midday on Thursday with the S&P 500 and Nasdaq orbiting their new record highs, while the Dow struggled to stay above water as investors digest moves by the European Central Bank against developments in Washington that could impede President Trump's ability to solidify support for his fiscal stimulus policies.

Into Thursday's open, stocks were cautiously higher as investors digested Q2 results from Qualcomm ( QCOM ) and Phillip Morris ( PM ), along with the decision by the European Central Bank to keep interest rates and its asset purchase program unchanged

But fresh off new record highs, Wall Street briefly retreated into negative territory following reports that Attorney General Jeff Sessions may resign after facing criticism from President Trump, and special counsel Robert Mueller was expanding his investigation into Trump's businesses, luring risk-adverse investors into gold and U.S. Treasuries.

Economic data was also a mixed bag, leaving little impression on Wall Street as an unexpectedly sharp drop in initial jobless claims was offset by a weaker-than-expected Philadelphia Fed business outlook index.
Neither sets of data -- as well as a 0.6% increase in leading economic indicators -- is likely to have an impact on Federal Reserve monetary policy.
European shares faltered under the weight of the soaring euro when comments made by European Central Bank president Mario Draghi indicated that QE tapering discussions would take place in the fall.
The euro skyrocketed to its highest level in newly two years, dragging EU government bond yields lower and most EU bourses into negative territory.
Crude oil was down $0.17 to $46.95 per barrel.
Natural gas was up $0.01 to $3.06 per 1 million BTU.
Gold was up $3.70 to $1,245.70 an ounce, while silver was u $0.08 to $16.37 an ounce.
Copper was up $0.01 to $2.71 per pound.
Among energy ETFs, the United States Oil Fund was down 0.41% to $9.65 with the United States Natural Gas Fund was up 0.07% to $6.87.
Amongst precious-metal funds, the Market Vectors Gold Miners ETF was up 0.83% to 22.36 while SPDR Gold Shares were up 0.35% to $118.49.
The iShares Silver Trust was up 0.55% to $15.48.

Here's where the markets stand at mid-day:

NYSE Composite Index was up $13.50 (+0.11%) to 11,954.97

Dow Jones Industrial Index was down 19.28 points (-0.09%) to 21,621.13

S&P 500 was up 2.38 points (+0.10%) to 2,476.17

Nasdaq Composite Index was up 11.00 points (+0.17%) to 6,396.08

FTSE 100 was up 56.96 points (+0.77%) to 7,487.87

DAX was down 4.80 points (-0.04%) to 12,447.25

CAC 40 was down 16.85 points (-0.32%) to 5,199.22

Nikkei 225 was up 123.73 points (+0.62%) to 20,144.59

Hang Seng Index was up 68.05 points (+0.26%) to 26,740.21

Shanghai China Composite Index was up 13.89 points (+0.43%) to 3,244.86

NYSE Energy Sector Index was up 9.02 points (+0.09%) to 10,308.87

NYSE Financial Sector Index was up 6.42 points (+0.08%) to 7,584.63

NYSE Healthcare Sector Index was up 119.44 points (+0.86%) to 13,933.82
